awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Feedback-Controlled Microfluidic Chips with Integrated Sensor Networks for Blood Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Efficient exchange of metabolic signals with other tissues turns the blood into an opportunity to monitor and diagnose physiological and pathological conditions. Among the constituents of blood, white blood cells represent a particularly rich source of information due to their active involvement in the immune response of the body. As such, technologies that can rapidly characterize blood samples and extract reliable information are in ever-increasing demand for both clinical and basic research applications. The proposed work aims to develop smart microchips that can reliably analyze white blood cells from small blood samples without any sample preparation. These microchips will be low-cost, disposable, and will include built-in electrodes that can convert the chemical information from white blood cells into electrical signals to be interpreted by a smartphone and transmitted to the healthcare provider. The proposed research therefore has the potential to revolutionize healthcare delivery by enabling people to self-administer blood tests at home or in mobile settings. Besides his research, the PI is fully committed to the educational aspects of his profession and aspires to be a role model for next-generation engineers. The PI's educational goal is to create application-focused multidisciplinary courses, research opportunities and learning experiences for students. To this end, the PI proposes (1) to organize innovation tournaments to develop micro/nanotechnologies for solving biomedical challenges, (2) to implement a laboratory module in the graduate- and undergraduate-level courses, (3) to involve and mentor undergraduate and graduate students in conducting the research activities of this proposal, (4) to mentor high school teachers to attract K-12 and High School Students and underrepresented groups to science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education.

Despite being highly effective in manipulating cells, microfluidic devices lack native sensing schemes and hence often act as upstream sample preparation elements before quantitative measurements typically performed with a laboratory instrument. The disconnect between microfluidic manipulation and quantitative measurements is an important limitation that hampers the widespread adoption of these tools outside of academic research laboratories, for example in resource-limited or in point-of-care settings, where they can be truly transformative in healthcare delivery. The PI's career goal is to develop polymer-based lab-on-a-chip (LoC) platforms with built-in sensor networks, whose purposely simple hardware will be augmented by complex computational algorithms, to function as content-aware, autonomous microfluidic devices for quantitative cell analysis. To achieve this goal, the PI will adopt a highly multidisciplinary approach combining traditionally-distant disciplines such as microsystem engineering, information theory, data science, and biomedicine. This proposal will (1) design and fabricate plastic microfluidic chips wired with networks of
interconnected electrical micro-sensors, each individually designed to produce a signature response that can be recognized among others through computation, (2) develop computational algorithms to process compressed data from the sensor network by utilizing both model-based signal processing and machine learning approaches, (3) develop open- and closed-loop controlled microfluidic systems, where a host of
actuators are combined with spatiotemporal data generated by networked sensors to extract biological information from the sample under test, (4) combine all of the developed concepts to create an autonomous and adaptive microfluidic system that can analyze whole blood samples by label-free immunophenotyping of white blood cells.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Lab-on-a-chip (LoC) devices aim to execute tasks conventionally performed in a laboratory at the microchip level. As such these devices offer great potential for developing biomedical tests to be used at home or at the point of care for diagnosing or monitoring various health anomalies. However, these devices, although very successful in separating pathogenic cells from normal cells, they lack built-in sensors to report this separation process as actionable data. The research goal of this project was to develop LoC devices with integrated electrical sensor networks that can directly convert manipulation of cells within the device to signals that can readily be processed, stored or transmitted ultimately enabling telehealth applications. Another goal of the project was to analyze these signals in real-time to optimize the operation of the LoC device to automatically adapt the test to the biological sample under test. Finally, we proposed to apply the developed technologies to analyze blood cells because blood is of great interest as it can be used to monitor and diagnose physiological and pathological conditions.

At the end of the project, we have achieved our proposed goals. We have developed a variety of on-chip electrical sensor network architectures that allowed us to monitor the movement of cells as they are physically separated from each other through a number of different modalities. Moreover, we characterized the developed sensors and established models that link the sensor performance to the sample properties. Concurrently, we developed signal processing algorithm that used machine learning and deep learning models to automatically and rapidly interpret the sensor data. We demonstrated the device operation can be successfully controlled based on the signals from cells within the microchip. Finally, we developed microchips which were able to analyze white blood cells and measure the fractions of different subpopulations that are monitored in a doctor visit. We validated the results from our tests with traditional bulky instruments and demonstrated practical implementations of the developed technology. In terms of the intellectual merit, a multidisciplinary approach combining microsystem engineering, computational approaches and biomedicine was developed. This work combined data multiplexing techniques traditionally used in telecommunications with microfluidics to develop sensing architectures that allowed a large network of sensors could be integrated onto a single microfluidic chip without the need for complex instrumentation.

The results from this project were disseminated to the academic community in the from peer-reviewed publications in international research journals and as presentations in conferences. Our findings were also shared with the public via a webpage, seminars open to public and news releases from the university following academic publications. The project was also successful in terms of technology translation. The university filed multiple patent applications on the technology developed from this award. In addition, some of the technologies developed in this application were explored for commercialization in a follow up funding from National Science Foundation I-Corps program.

The educational goals of this project were to (1) integrate research findings into teaching programs and (2) to develop graduate workforce for biotechnology development and (3) to create opportunities for undergraduate and high school students to experience scientific research. To those ends, the research results were successfully integrated into courses on biotechnology taken by students from electrical, mechanical and biomedical engineering graduate students. Besides supporting multiple graduate students towards a doctorate degree, this project also created research opportunities for numerous undergraduate and high school students from a variety engineering and scientific disciplines.

Taken together, this project developed technical concepts that moved the research-grade biochips a step closer to be used in practice as at home tests with sample to answer capability and also helped create educational opportunities for developing a student body equipped with multidisciplinary skills needed to tackle challenges at the interface of engineering and biomedicine.
